# List of Manchester United F.C. managers

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![A side-on photograph of a man with grey hair. He is wearing glasses and a
black
overcoat.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Alex_Ferguson.jpg/170px-
Alex_Ferguson.jpg)](/wiki/File:Alex_Ferguson.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Alex_Ferguson.jpg "Enlarge")

[Sir Alex Ferguson](/wiki/Sir_Alex_Ferguson "Sir Alex Ferguson"), the most
decorated manager in the history of [Manchester
United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.")

[Manchester United Football Club](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester
United F.C.") is an English professional [football](/wiki/Association_football
"Association football") club based in [Old
Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford,_Greater_Manchester "Old Trafford, Greater
Manchester"), [Greater Manchester](/wiki/Greater_Manchester "Greater
Manchester"). The club was formed in [Newton Heath](/wiki/Newton_Heath "Newton
Heath") in 1878 as Newton Heath LYR F.C., and played their first competitive
match in October 1886, when they entered the First Round of the [1886–87 FA
Cup](/wiki/1886%E2%80%9387_FA_Cup "1886–87 FA Cup"). The club was renamed
Manchester United F.C. in 1902, and moved to [Old Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford
"Old Trafford") in 1910.

From the beginning of the club's official managerial records in 1892 to the
start of the [2017–18
season](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Manchester_United_F.C._season "2017–18
Manchester United F.C. season"), [Manchester
United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.") have had 22
full-time managers. The current manager is [José
Mourinho](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mourinho "José Mourinho") who took over from [Louis
van Gaal](/wiki/Louis_van_Gaal "Louis van Gaal") on 27 May 2016.

The longest-serving and most successful person to manage Manchester United is
[Sir Alex Ferguson](/wiki/Alex_Ferguson "Alex Ferguson"), who won 13 [Premier
League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League") titles, five [FA
Cups](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup"), four [League Cups](/wiki/Football_League_Cup
"Football League Cup"), 10 [Community Shields](/wiki/FA_Community_Shield "FA
Community Shield"), two [UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League
"UEFA Champions League") titles, one [UEFA Cup Winners'
Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup"), one [UEFA Super
Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Super_Cup "UEFA Super Cup"), one [Intercontinental
Cup](/wiki/Intercontinental_Cup_\(football\) "Intercontinental Cup
\(football\)") and one [FIFA Club World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Club_World_Cup "FIFA
Club World Cup") in his managerial reign of more than 26 years.

## Managerial
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Manchester_United_F.C._managers&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Managerial history")]

From 1878 to 1914, the team was selected by a committee whose secretary had
the same powers and role as a manager has today. There were four secretaries
during this period, [A. H. Albut](/wiki/A._H._Albut "A. H. Albut"), [James
West](/wiki/James_West_\(football_manager\) "James West \(football
manager\)"), [Ernest Mangnall](/wiki/Ernest_Mangnall "Ernest Mangnall") and
[John Bentley](/wiki/John_Bentley_\(football_manager\) "John Bentley
\(football manager\)").

Ernest Mangnall was the first man to bring any major silverware to the club,
winning the club's first ever [Football League](/wiki/The_Football_League "The
Football League") title in 1908. This was followed by the [FA
Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup") the following season, and another league title in
1911. Despite this success, though, he left the club a year later to join
local rivals [Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C. "Manchester City
F.C."). Coincidentally, Mangnall's last match in charge of United was the Old
Trafford derby of 7 September 1912.[1] John Bentley took over as club
secretary, but was replaced two years later by [Jack Robson](/wiki/Jack_Robson
"Jack Robson"), who became the club's first full-time manager. He remained in
the post for seven years, but resigned in December 1921 after succumbing to a
bout of pneumonia.[2]

Robson was followed soon after by [John
Chapman](/wiki/John_Chapman_\(football_manager\) "John Chapman \(football
manager\)"). However, in Chapman's first season at the club, they were
relegated to the [Second Division](/wiki/Football_League_Second_Division
"Football League Second Division") for the first time since 1906. Three years
in the Second Division followed, before promotion back to the [First
Division](/wiki/Football_League_First_Division "Football League First
Division"). After guiding the club to 9th place in the league and the FA Cup
semi-finals in [1925–26](/wiki/1925%E2%80%9326_Manchester_United_F.C._season
"1925–26 Manchester United F.C. season"), Chapman received a
[telegram](/wiki/Telegraphy "Telegraphy") from [the Football
Association](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The Football Association") on 8
October 1926 informing him of his suspension from management for the rest of
the season; no reason was given. Half-back [Lal Hilditch](/wiki/Lal_Hilditch
"Lal Hilditch") took over for the remainder of the season, before [Herbert
Bamlett](/wiki/Herbert_Bamlett "Herbert Bamlett") took permanent control.

Bamlett was manager for four years, but was unable to muster any success, the
club's highest position during his reign being 12th.[3] The club was relegated
to the Second Division again in 1931, and Bamlett was replaced by club
secretary [Walter Crickmer](/wiki/Walter_Crickmer "Walter Crickmer"). This was
Crickmer's first of two spells as manager of the club, retaining his position
as secretary all the while. It lasted only a season, though, as he failed to
return the club to the First Division. In June 1932, [Scott
Duncan](/wiki/Scott_Duncan_\(footballer\) "Scott Duncan \(footballer\)") was
appointed as manager, but in his second season in charge he led the club to
what remains a club record lowest League position; 20th in the Second
Division. The club held faith in Duncan though, and he managed to get the club
back into the First Division by 1936. However, the club was relegated again
the following year, and Walter Crickmer resumed control until the end of the
[Second World War](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").

Before the end of the war, the club approached [Matt Busby](/wiki/Matt_Busby
"Matt Busby"), who had just turned down the opportunity to join the coaching
staff at [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C. "Liverpool F.C."), on the grounds
that he wanted more responsibility over the playing side of the club than
merely the selection of the team.[3] United allowed Busby the responsibilities
he requested, and in his first five seasons in charge he guided the team to
four second-place finishes in the league, before finally winning his first
title in 1952. He soon set about replacing many of the more experienced
players with a group of youths who came to be known as the "[Busby
Babes](/wiki/Busby_Babes "Busby Babes")". This team went on to win two league
titles in [1955–56](/wiki/1955%E2%80%9356_Manchester_United_F.C._season
"1955–56 Manchester United F.C. season") and
[1956–57](/wiki/1956%E2%80%9357_Manchester_United_F.C._season "1956–57
Manchester United F.C. season"), as well as reaching two FA Cup finals.
Unfortunately, the careers of many of the players were cut short by the
[Munich air disaster](/wiki/Munich_air_disaster "Munich air disaster"), which
also left Busby fighting for his life.[4]

While Busby was in hospital recovering from the injuries he sustained in the
air crash, his managerial duties were left to his assistant, [Jimmy
Murphy](/wiki/Jimmy_Murphy_\(footballer\) "Jimmy Murphy \(footballer\)").
After Busby recovered, he set about rebuilding his side, and within five
years, in [1963](/wiki/1963_FA_Cup_Final "1963 FA Cup Final"), he had won the
FA Cup for the first time in 15 years. This was followed up by two league
titles in three years, and then the greatest prize in European club football,
the [European Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League"). He
continued as manager for one more year after this success, leaving his
managerial duties to club trainer [Wilf McGuinness](/wiki/Wilf_McGuinness
"Wilf McGuinness"). McGuinness struggled in his new post, however, and Busby
was convinced to return for the second half of the [1970–71
season](/wiki/1970%E2%80%9371_Manchester_United_F.C._season "1970–71
Manchester United F.C. season").[4] However, he retired from football
permanently that summer, and was succeeded that summer by [Frank
O'Farrell](/wiki/Frank_O%27Farrell "Frank O'Farrell"). O'Farrell's stay was
short-lived, though, as his inability to control [George
Best](/wiki/George_Best "George Best")'s extravagances forced the board to
sack him with three years still to run on his contract.

O'Farrell's replacement was to be
[Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team "Scotland national football
team") coach, [Tommy Docherty](/wiki/Tommy_Docherty "Tommy Docherty").
Docherty left the Scotland job and his first task at United was to keep the
club in the top flight. He managed it once, but he was unable to pull it off
again and the club was relegated in
[1973–74](/wiki/1973%E2%80%9374_Manchester_United_F.C._season "1973–74
Manchester United F.C. season"). They bounced straight back up the following
season, though, and in their first season back in the top flight, the team
cruised to a third-place finish and yet another [FA Cup
final](/wiki/1976_FA_Cup_Final "1976 FA Cup Final"). The next year, they went
one better, beating Liverpool in the [final](/wiki/1977_FA_Cup_Final "1977 FA
Cup Final") to claim his first and only trophy at [Old
Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford "Old Trafford"). It was soon discovered, however,
that Docherty was having an affair with the wife of the club's
physiotherapist, and he was immediately fired,[5] replaced by [Queens Park
Rangers](/wiki/Queens_Park_Rangers_F.C. "Queens Park Rangers F.C.")' manager
[Dave Sexton](/wiki/Dave_Sexton "Dave Sexton").

Sexton remained in the United job for four years, but was unable to produce
any silverware, and was replaced in 1981 by [Ron Atkinson](/wiki/Ron_Atkinson
"Ron Atkinson"). Atkinson was able to rekindle the club's cup success, leading
his side to two FA Cups in his five-year tenure. He also oversaw a series of
respectable finishes in the league, but after his disastrous start to the
[1986–87 season](/wiki/1986%E2%80%9387_Manchester_United_F.C._season "1986–87
Manchester United F.C. season"), he was sacked.[6] His replacement, Alex
Ferguson, had, in recent years, become the first manager to break the
dominance of [Rangers](/wiki/Rangers_F.C. "Rangers F.C.") and
[Celtic](/wiki/Celtic_F.C. "Celtic F.C.") in the Scottish league for over 15
years, winning the Scottish Premier Division title with
[Aberdeen](/wiki/Aberdeen_F.C. "Aberdeen F.C.") three times in six years, as
well as finishing as runner-up twice and winning the European Cup-Winners Cup.

During his tenure, Ferguson was credited with the distinction of making some
of the most shrewd purchases in the club's history, including the signings of
[Peter Schmeichel](/wiki/Peter_Schmeichel "Peter Schmeichel") and [Eric
Cantona](/wiki/Eric_Cantona "Eric Cantona"), each for less than £1.5
million.[7] With these signings, combined with the club's many experienced
players, Ferguson brought the league title back to Old Trafford for the first
time in 26 years. In the following decade, he won the Premier League title
another six times, including a hat-trick of titles from 1999 to 2001, a feat
that no other manager has yet achieved with the same club.[8] In 1999, he also
led the club to an unprecedented Treble of [Premier
League](/wiki/1998%E2%80%9399_FA_Premier_League "1998–99 FA Premier League"),
[FA Cup](/wiki/1999_FA_Cup_Final "1999 FA Cup Final") and [UEFA Champions
League](/wiki/1999_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "1999 UEFA Champions League
Final"). Subsequently, he added another three league titles to his trophy
haul, despite a number of promises of retirement.[9] Ferguson won his 10th
Premier League title in the [2007–08
season](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_Premier_League "2007–08 Premier League"), and
followed this up with his second Champions League title 10 days later. In
[2008–09](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_Premier_League "2008–09 Premier League"),
Ferguson guided United to another Premier League title, making Manchester
United the only club and him the only manager to have won the English league
title three times in a row twice. His 12th title, in the
[2010–11](/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Premier_League "2010–11 Premier League")
season, was United's 19th overall, overtaking [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C.
"Liverpool F.C.")'s record of 18. Ferguson won his 13th and final league title
in the [2012–13](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_Premier_League "2012–13 Premier
League") season, making 20 titles overall for United. At the end of the
season, Ferguson announced his retirement, and he was replaced by
[Everton](/wiki/Everton_F.C. "Everton F.C.") manager [David
Moyes](/wiki/David_Moyes "David Moyes").[10]

In his first match, Moyes gave United their 20th Community Shield and his
first trophy as United manager; however, after failing to lead the club to
Champions League qualification, he was sacked before the end of his first
season, with [Ryan Giggs](/wiki/Ryan_Giggs "Ryan Giggs") taking temporary
charge for the final four games of the 2013–14 season where the club finished
seventh, their lowest league finish since the establishment of the Premier
League.[11] [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team
"Netherlands national football team") manager [Louis van
Gaal](/wiki/Louis_van_Gaal "Louis van Gaal") was appointed as Moyes' permanent
replacement on 19 May 2014, taking charge after the end of the [2014 FIFA
World Cup](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup").[12] In his
inaugural season, United signed many prominent players and returned to the
Champions League with a 4th-place finish. In his second season, United
finished in 5th place behind [Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C.
"Manchester City F.C."), out of Champions League position, but won the [2016
FA Cup](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_FA_Cup "2015–16 FA Cup"), the club's first in a
dozen years. The board, however, decided that not enough progress had been
made from the previous season and Van Gaal was sacked on 23 May 2016, just
days after lifting the cup. He was replaced by two-time European champion and
former [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C.") boss [José
Mourinho](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mourinho "José Mourinho") on 27 May 2016. Mourinho
became United's fourth manager (including Giggs) in as many years since
Ferguson's retirement.

##
Statistics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Manchester_United_F.C._managers&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Statistics")]

_Information correct as of 31 October 2017. Only competitive matches are
counted._

Table headers

  * **Nationality** – If the manager played international football as a player, the country/countries he played for are shown. Otherwise, the manager's nationality is given as their country of birth.
  * **From** – The year of the manager's first game for Manchester United.
  * **To** – The year of the manager's last game for Manchester United.
  * **P** – The number of games managed for Manchester United.
  * **W** – The number of games won as a manager.
  * **D** – The number of games draw as a manager.
  * **L** – The number of games lost as a manager.
  * **GF** – The number of goals scored under his management.
  * **GA** – The number of goals conceded under his management.
  * **Win%** – The total [winning percentage](/wiki/Winning_percentage "Winning percentage") under his management.
  * **Honours** – The trophies won while managing Manchester United.

Key

  * (n/a) = Information _not available_
  * p = Player-manager

  3. **Jump up ^** Information regarding A. H. Albut's managerial record is unavailable due to his exact date of appointment being unknown.

  5. **Jump up ^** Murphy was installed as the club's caretaker manager while Busby was in hospital recovering from the Munich air disaster.
  6. **Jump up ^** Five of Ferguson's Community Shields were won while the competition was still known as the FA Charity Shield.
